facts.text: Appeal filed in Supreme Court as Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from High Court judgment dated 5th January 1953 by Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench, Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 5th January, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Lucknow

facts.text: High Court appeal was Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Bench , Lucknow  Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.  in Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4

facts.text: Sessions Court judgment dated 19th January 1952 by Sessions Judge, Sitapur in Sessions Case No. 97 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: of 1952 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 19th January 1952, of the Court of the Sessions Judge, Sitapur, in

facts.text: Three appellants prosecuted for murder of Babu Singh.

anchor.surface_text: We have three appellants before us. All were prosecuted for the murder of one Babu Singh.

facts.text: Surendra Singh convicted of murder and sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: Of these, Surendra Singh alone was convicted of the murder and was sentenced to death.

facts.text: Other two appellants convicted under section 225 Indian Penal Code, sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 200.

anchor.surface_text: The other two were convicted under section 225, Indian Penal Code. Each was sentenced to three years rigorous impriso

facts.text: All three appealed to High Court at Allahabad Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: All three appealed to the High Court at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench  and the appeal was heard

facts.text: High Court appeal heard on 5th December 1952 by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

anchor.surface_text: and the appeal was heard on Filth December, 1952, by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.  Judgment was reserved.

facts.text: Judgment reserved after hearing.

anchor.surface_text: Judgment was reserved. Before it could be delivered Bhargava J. was transferred to Allahabad.

facts.text: Bhargava J. transferred to Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: Before it could be delivered Bhargava J. was transferred to Allahabad. While there he dictated a,

facts.text: Bhargava J. dictated judgment purporting to be joint judgment using 'we', signed every page but did not date it.

anchor.surface_text: judgment purporting to do so on behalf of himself and his brother Judge, that is to say it purported to be a joint judgment he used the pronoun we and number I. He signed every page of the judgment as well as at the end but did number date it.

facts.text: Bhargava J. sent the judgment to Kidwai J. at Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: He then sent this to Kidwai J. at Lucknow. He died on 24th December, 1962, before the judgment

facts.text: Bhargava J. died on 24th December 1952.

anchor.surface_text: He died on 24th December, 1962, before the judgment was delivered. After his death, on 5th January,

facts.text: On 5th January 1953, Kidwai J. purported to deliver the judgment of the court, signed and dated it 5th January 1953.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, on 5th January, 1953, his brother Judge Kidwai J. purported to deliver the judgment of the court. He signed it and dated it. The date he placed on it was 5th January, 1953,

facts.text: High Court dismissed the appeal and confirmed the death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava J.s signature was still there and anyone reading the judgment and number knowing the facts would conclude that Bhargava J. was a party to the delivery on 5th January, 1953. The appeal was dismissed

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Rules framed in 1952, came into force on 15th September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad High Court framed its present set of Rules in 1952. They came into force on the 15th of September in that year.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by BOSE J. on November 16, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the High Court judgment invalid because Bhargava J. died before delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, remanded for re-hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court which purports to be its judgment is set aside. As it is no longer possible for the Bench which heard the appeal and the confirmation proceedings to deliver a valid judgment we send the case back to the High Court for re-hearing and delivery of a proper judgment.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: Jai Gopal Sethi, K. P. Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: Jai Gopal Sethi  K. P. Gupta, with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: C. Mathur and Onkar Nath Srivastava.

anchor.surface_text: C. Mathur and Onkar Nath Srivastava for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 23. BOSE J.The order for stay dated the 25th May, 1953, has not expended itself.

anchor.surface_text: We have three appellants before us. All were prosecuted for the murder of one Babu Singh. Of these, Surendra Singh alone was companyvicted of the murder and was sentenced to death.

issues.text: whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed and the sentence of death was confirmed. The question is whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal. The arguments covered a wide range but we intend to confine ourselves to the facts of this case and only deal with the narrower issues which arise here.

issues.text: what is a judgment, for it is the judgment which decides the case and affects the rights and liberties of the parties

anchor.surface_text: the question still remains what is a judgment, for it is the judgment which decides the case and affects the rights and liberties of the parties that is the core of the matter and, as the Privy Council say, the whole purpose of these rules is to secure certainty in the ascertainment of what the judgment was.

issues.text: whether a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things

anchor.surface_text: These rules use the word pronounced in some places and delivered in others. Counsel tried to make capital out of this and said that a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things. We do not intend to construe these rules too technically

arguments.claim: a judgment is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

arguments.claim: Judges have locus poenitentiae to change their mind until the moment of formal delivery of judgment

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur.

arguments.claim: a signed draft judgment is not operative until formally delivered in open court

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court. Only then does it crystallise into a full fledged judgment and become operative.

arguments.claim: it is against public policy to investigate whether a signed draft was intended as final judgment or tentative

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft...

arguments.claim: signed drafts handed in before delivery do not constitute judgments of the court (citing Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee)

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

holdings.text: The judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed draft purporting to be joint judgment not formally delivered in open court before Bhargava J.'s death; requires extant Bench for valid delivery under CrPC s369 and High Court rules.

holdings.text: A judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of rules is certainty; judgment operative only upon formal public intimation; distinguishes core act from authentication irregularities curable by s537 CrPC.

holdings.text: These rules use the word pronounced in some places and delivered in others... a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things... We do not intend to construe these rules too technically.

anchor.surface_text: These rules use the word pronounced in some places and delivered in others. Counsel tried to make capital out of this and said that a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things. We do not intend to construe these rules too technically

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules designed to further ends of justice, not technical distinctions; provide for various situations of pronouncement/delivery interchangeably.

holdings.text: Section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil... But even after every allowance is made... the question still remains what is a judgment.

anchor.surface_text: But in truth the difficulty is disposed of by sections 99 and 108, Civil Procedure Code. That was a civil case. This is a criminal one. But section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cures irregularities in authentication/manner but not absence of core formal delivery/pronouncement constituting the judgment itself.

holdings.text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect... The defect is merely an irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The case of a Judge who has gone on leave before signing the judgment may call for more comment, but even so the convenience of the court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Privy Council in Firm Gokal Chand; applies to signing/authentication defects post-delivery, not lack of delivery itself.

holdings.text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae.

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explains why delivery is essential: preserves right to alter until formal act; signed drafts remain tentative.

holdings.text: However much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court. Only then does it crystallise into a full fledged judgment and become operative.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court. Only then does it crystallise into a full fledged judgment and become operative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delivery is operative judicial act; pre-delivery signatures/drafts non-binding to allow locus poenitentiae.

holdings.text: It follows that the Judge who delivers the judgment... must be in existence as a member of the court at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the Judge who delivers the judgment, or causes it to be delivered by a brother Judge, must be in existence as a member of the court at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery and say that he has changed his mind.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessity of living judge for potential last-minute change; cannot assume no change post-death.

holdings.text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion.

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents speculation/conjecture on deceased judge's final intent; requires certainty via formal delivery.

holdings.text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court... all nine Judges were unanimous in holding that those three opinions could not be regarded as judgments in the formal sense of the term. In our opinion, Jackson J. expressed the law aright.

In that case, three of the seven Judges... all nine Judges were unanimous in holding that those three opinions could not be regarded as judgments in the formal sense of the term.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signed drafts handed pre-delivery not judgments; approves Mahomed Akil precedent where judges retired/died before delivery.

anchor.surface_text: As this decision of the Judicial Committee was relied on in the arguments we will quote the passage which is relevant here. It is at page 295 of Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram 1 . The facts are number the same as here because the judgment was actually delivered in open companyrt and both the judges who companystituted the Bench were present and companycurred in it. But before it companyld be signed, one Judge went on leave. A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 292. The rules required the judgment to be signed and dated at the time that it was pronounced. Their Lordships said-

precedents.case_name: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: court has inherent jurisdiction to supply defects in judgment authentication caused by judge death or leave after pronouncement; rules are directory and irregularity curable
precedents.cited_holding: The companyrt must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The defect is merely an irregularity. But in truth the difficulty is disposed of by sections 99 and 108, Civil Procedure Code.

precedents.citation: Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 ... 9 W.R.I. F.B.

anchor.surface_text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court companysisting of nine Judges in the year 1867 in Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 . In that case, three of the seven Judges who companystituted the Bench handed in signed judgments to the Registrar of the companyrt. Before the judgment companyld be delivered, two of them retired and one died. A Full Bench of nine Judges was companyvened to companysider whether the drafts of those three Judges companyld be accepted as judgments of the companyrt. Seton-Kerr J., who had heard the case along with them, said-- Certainly as far as I can recollect, they appeared to have fully made up their minds on a subject which they had very seriously companysidered, and on which they had abundant opportunities of forming a final determination. I am, however. number prepared to say that they might number on further companysideration have changed their opinions  p. 13 .

precedents.cited_proposition: signed drafts are not formal judgments until delivered in open court; cannot be delivered after judge death or retirement
precedents.cited_holding: it was necessary in strict practice that judgments should be delivered and pronounced in open companyrt. [...] Judges who have died or have retired from the companyrt cannot join in the judgment which is to be delivered today [...] A judgment in the eye of the law is the final decision of the whole companyrt.
